name: KC 85/1 - Z 9001
keyboard: QWERTZ-Layout, 65 keys. VERY hard to type with
ram: 17 KB (16 KB free), expandable to 64 KB max.
rom: 6 KB (4 KB OS + 2 KB character map)
graphics: Graphics only possible with 128 pre-defined graphic and 96 text symbols in text mode (8x8 pixels size)
colors: B/W, optional color module (then 8 foreground & 8 background colors)
sound: Integrated beeper; Mono sound module with 8 volumes & 6 octaves
ports: B/W TV output through HF-modulator, Tape interface (DIN), I/0 connector (DIN),  2 Joysticks connectors, 4 module slotsAfter RGB-Upgrade: 1 connector for 2 Joysticks, 1 connector for RGB color output
description:
The KC85/1 was originally introduced as the HC-9001, "HC" meaning "Home Computer". But as the industry demand for computers was so high, they even used these home computers, so the name was changed to KC85/1, "KC" standing for "KleinComputer", which could be translated to "Small Computer".

The machine had very limited graphical capabilities with 128 pre-defined graphic and 96 text symbols in text mode (8x8 pixels size). The BASIC language needs to be loaded from cassette every time you needed it (or you could also get it as an optional ROM Module). It has got an awful keyboard (3 x 10 mm plastic keys), which was quite a pain to type with for a long time.

There was probably no real reason to prefer it from the other available models, except its low price, compared to its bigger and more featured brothers.

_____

Info kindly provided by Stefan Goehler.

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 ADVERT & PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Price list</b><br><br>  <b>VP-111  </b>Low cost microcomputer  <b>$99</b><br> <b>VP-114  </b>Expansion kit for VP-111 (3 KB RAM, I/O port and connectors)  <b>$76</b><br> <b>VP-711  </b>Original VIP microcomputer <b>$199</b><br> <b>VP-44    </b>On board RAM expansion (4 x 2114 RAM chips)  <b>$36</b><br> <b>VP-590  </b>Color board  <b>$69</b><br> <b>VP-595  </b>Simple sound board (256 programmable frequencies) with speaker  <b>$30</b><br> <b>VP-550  </b>Super sound board (Synthetiser with two sound channels  <b>$49</b><br> <b>VP-551  </b>Super sound 4 channels expansion <b>$74</b><br> <b>VP-570  </b>4 KB RAM memory expansion board  <b>$95</b><br> <b>VP-580  </b>Two players keypad  <b>$20</b><br> <b>VP-585  </b>Keypad interface board  <b>$15</b><br> <b>VP-560  </b>Eprom board for two 2716 EPROMS  <b>$34</b><br> <b>VP-565  </b>2716 EPROM programmer with software  <b>$99</b><br> <b>VP-575  </b>Expansion board with 5 expansions sockets  <b>$59</b><br> <b>VP-700  </b>4 KB Tiny Basic  <b>$39</b><br> <b>VP-701  </b>Floating point Basic (cassette)  <b>$49</b><br> <b>VP-710  </b>Game listings  <b>$10</b><br> <b>VP-720  </b>Game listings II  <b>$15</b><br> <b>VP-601  </b>Keyboard 128-character ASCII  <b>$69</b> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>According to this brochure, Newbury had four models:<br><br> Model M: Main Only<br> Model MB: Main and with Batteries and display<br> Model MD: Mains only with display<br> Model MBS: Main and with Batteries and display with special low power consumption.  <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> ...You will get more performances than with the IBM PC, the Apple II, TRS80 Model II or TRS80 Model III along with software support of TRSDOS or CP/M, the two most widely used operating systems. This means you, the user, can select from the largest base of business or personal software... <font></blockquote>

media: none; external cassette player required (connected via DIN connector)
peripherals: Color upgrade, Sound module, Basic on ROM, 16 KB RAM modules, 10 KB module with room for self-programmed ROM?s, ADC module, DAC module
